entry.title: Robot Control Unit
entry.content:
controller board with stepper drivers
power supply (25W) to provide power to the controller and onboard computer
test fitting the components
❮ ❯

Description

This [hardware assembly] was made for an indoor differential drive robot with a two-axis gimbal.

At its core is the controller board (center). It consists of:

  • a STM32F7 MCU
  • 6DOF IMU, 3DOF magnetometer
  • 4x configurable TMC stepper drivers with all bells and whistles hooked up
  • connectors for an LCD, and several peripherals
  • 2x servo connectors
  • 1x ibus receiver
  • 1x serial connector (SWD + UART) to the onboard computer (Raspberry Pi)

The board is programmable remotely via the Raspberry's GPIO port and openocd. During the development of the robot, this has proven not only to be a huge time saver but it also frees the robot of all wires that would otherwise restrain it in its motion.

Its primary function is to serve as an interface between the onboard computer and the hardware. It also takes care of all the critical real-time tasks such as step generation (ramp profiles), AHRS updates, reading the remote control inputs, etc. Finally, it also assumes safety-critical functions such as preventing the robot from driving down a stairwell or colliding with obstacles.

The board is powered by a [5V, 25W buck converter] using the AP64501 from Analog Devices, the same chip also used on Raspberry's compute module carrier board. Power monitoring also takes place here. Since the robot operates on batteries, it is important to keep track of its voltage and the energy it consumes.

The firmware of this board is a bit unusual and breaks with the custom of being written in the languages traditionally used for embedded systems, namely C or C++. Instead, it is written from the ground up in rust for two good reasons:

  1. correctness. Every sufficiently complex software can be affected by memory corruption (e.g., due to a dangling pointer), which is not only hard to spot, but also extremely challenging to reproduce and debug. Even worse, it can go unnoticed, until it happens in the field where the system cannot be serviced and/or cause damage. Of course, rigorous coding discipline and best practices get you pretty far in C/C++, but having the compiler eliminate a whole range of possible bugs is a huge win and a competitive edge. If it compiles, it works (apart from logic errors).
  2. async. Contrary to C/C++, async functionality is a core part of the rust language. It enables fearless concurrent programming (tasks scheduled by an executor to run on a single core) written as if executed sequentially. This is beneficial for almost anything IO bound such as web servers, databases, and also embedded systems. While MCUs have hardware built in (DMA) to offload IO operations and to keep the application running, this can become quite a burden to manage properly often resulting in complex state machines. By writing this code asynchronously, most of the complexity goes away. Herein, the rtic framework was used with the embassy-stm32 HAL. The former provides the scaffolding (similar to FreeRTOS), and the latter provides access to the STM32 peripherals and also implements the needed traits for async execution. Notice that rust async uses cooperative scheduling, as opposed to preemptive scheduling in FreeRTOS. A noticeable advantage of this approach is that there is no separate stack per task and thus no stack size tuning, faster task switches, and overall better resource utilization 1 2. A possible downside is that tasks that don't yield can starve other tasks.
  3. tooling Embedded rust has some impressive tools and libraries such as defmt for very efficient, lightweight data logging. embedded-hal enables portability between platforms by providing a set of useful traits. probe-rs is the de facto standard for flashing and debugging. defmt-test provides a hardness to run unit tests on bare metal with relative ease.

Overall, the embedded rust ecosystem has matured massively over the last couple of years. Some vendors (espressif and infineon) even started providing official support for their hardware, while others are still a pure community effort (STM32).

1

https://tweedegolf.nl/en/blog/65/async-rust-vs-rtos-showdown

2

https://interrupt.memfault.com/blog/embedded-async-rust

entry.title: Aerial Grasping: Simulation and Control
entry.content:
the aerial system: UAV, gripper, camera
semantic gripper model
equivalent simulation model
block diagram of the controller with force and trajectory control subsystems
the test scenario
simulation & test environment
grasping the payload
❮ ❯

Description

This project's main objective was to automate aerial grasping with universal jamming grippers, as manually controlling this operation quickly overburdens the drone operator. This project had three distinct goals:

  1. Convert the modeling insights gained here into a gazebo model
  2. Develop and implement a suitable control strategy for the universal jamming gripper
  3. Test the system in simulation

Simulation Model

Starting from the [mental model] developed earlier, an [analogous model] suitable for simulation had to be found. Since gazebo (the robotics simulator) cannot handle soft body dynamics, the gripper's model had to be simplified to represent the important characteristics of the gripper, namely:

  • the transition from soft to rigid
  • the change of volume (shrinking of the membrane) due to the variable air content in the membrane
  • the elastic/springy behavior depending on the air content

A precise model of the gripper's membrane's shape was not seen as a major factor in achieving a faithful simulation model (and it could not be achieved with gazebo alone).

To achieve the requirements, the gripper was modeled as a uniaxial, variable spring acting on a disc shape attached to a prismatic joint. The force to apply to that joint is governed by the law developed previously, which depends on the depth of entry, and the air content in the membrane. A gazebo plugin applies force to the joint and provides feedback on the contact force. It also takes care of necessary ros integration and creates and breaks 'joints' with the payload to grasp and release the payloads. The gripper was then [attached] to a UAV and a simulated depth camera.

Control Strategy

The goal here is to have a reliable control strategy that:

  • guides our UAV effectively towards the payload following a trajectory that preferably avoids obstacles it encounters
  • keep a well-defined contact force between the gripper and the payload while the pumps are running

The trajectory is obtained by repeatedly solving a non-linear optimization problem. This receding-horizon optimization scheme uses a simple kinematic model (the 'dynamics' of the UAV) and a cost function that encourages the desired behaviors. The behaviors herein were:

  • tracking (get closer to the goal)
  • repulsion (stay away from obstacles)
  • perception (keep the goal in the field of view)
  • grasping (approach the goal from the top and minimize motion in the horizontal plane)

Upon contact with the payload, the control scheme is [switched from trajectory control to force control]. During pump activation, a sliding mode controller keeps the contact force close to the desired level. This is an important aspect as any loss in contact force would result in a reduced contact surface and therefore increase the likelihood of a failed grasp.

Virtual Experiment

To conclude, a test scenario was set up where a payload is a priori roughly located in a [parking garage]. There are plenty of obstacles to be avoided by the UAV. The camera is used to refine the goal position as soon as it enters its field of view. In this scenario, the aerial system takes off, travels, refines the location of the payload, [picks it up], transports it to a safe area to be disposed of, and finally lands back on the gripper.

entry.title: ESDF Generation
entry.content:
the blockwise esdf generation process

Description

Euclidean Signed Distance Fields (ESDF) are used to infer the closest distance at any point to the nearest surface in a voxel or pixel grid. As such, they are used in robotics, e.g., for navigation purposes, as an instrument to account for the robot's dimensions. Considering the distances stored in the grid, the robot's path can be kept clear from any obstacles simply by excluding cells with a distance below a given threshold.

The implementation of the ESDF algorithm shown [here] is derived from the nvblox algorithm 1, a highly optimized GPU-accelerated algorithm that works on a block-by-block (chunks) basis.

The core algorithm is divided into two phases:

  • sweep (staying within the block boundaries)
  • propagation (crossing the block boundaries)

During the sweep phase, the distances to any given surface in the block are calculated along all axes of the grid and in both directions. Thereby the distance of a cell is only updated if a smaller distance is found. The propagate phase accesses the neighboring blocks to propagate distances across boundaries. The algorithm stops once no more changes are made.

The sites (block index closest to the surface) are for bookkeeping purposes. In case of a block update (changed surfaces), all blocks containing sites of this block's index need to be cleared and reevaluated (thus enabling partial updates).

The nature of the algorithm allows easy parallel execution of the sweep phase since they do not cross block boundaries.

This project features a CPU-based implementation and a na√Øve GPU implementation using compute shaders on top of wgpu. The current GPU implementation is slower due to excessive buffer transfers.

1

Millane, Alexander, et al. "nvblox: GPU-Accelerated Incremental Signed Distance Field Mapping." arXiv preprint arXiv:2311.00626 (2023).

entry.title: STL Thumbnail Provider
entry.content:
❮ ❯

Description

This project was born out of the need to quickly find my .stl files on my cluttered desktop.

In essence, this is a library that parses a given .stl, generates a list of triangles, and then uses software rasterizing to render an image. This image is then handled according to the desktop environment's thumbnail infrastructure's needs.

Software rasterizing was a conscious choice for a multitude of reasons:

  • portability between different platforms
  • to avoid driver issues and limitations due to sandboxing and library size (e.g., Gnome uses sandboxing and thumbnail generators have to access to the GPU).

The rendering quality is a bit lower and slower compared to GPU-accelerated rendering. However it could technically run even on a MCU found in 3D printers as the complete model doesn't even need to be kept in memory, and triangles can be read and rendered one by one.

The rendering process is as follows:

  • for each triangle in the stl
    • transform triangle from world- to screen-space
    • calculate its bounds in screen-space
    • iterate over the bounds and check if the pixel P is inside the triangle
      • calculate P's color (considering the light source and material properties)
      • perform a z-test (check if it is closer to the camera than the current P) and put P's color into the image

The initial project was written in C++ and then ported to Rust at a later stage with support for the Windows desktop and automated builds on Github's CI/CD infrastructure. The Windows support is particularly challenging as it requires implementing a poorly documented COM interface, registering the .dll upon installation, and setting the required registry keys. Gnome is a lot simpler; it simply runs an executable that generates a picture at a given location. Finally, KDE wants to see a shared library implementing the ThumbCreator interface.

entry.title: Cooperative Localization of UAVs
entry.content:
UAV equipped with cameras and ArUco markers
experimental setup (SnT aero lab)
❮ ❯

Description

Most UAVs nowadays are equipped with CCD cameras and also have enough grunt to do image processing in real-time. This capability can be used to improve (or enable) the localization of mobile robots. A marker attached to the UAV's body and the software Atlas written for this project is all that is needed to enable this functionality.

Herein, we used [ARUCO] markers (robust planar markers) from which a pose in the camera's frame is calculated. Atlas then dynamically generates a graph structure where

  • the nodes are robots
  • and the edges are relative transformations between them (including the covariance/standard deviation).

The edges between the nodes are automatically removed after some given time of inactivity (e.g., loss of visual contact). At any given time, an estimate of a robot's pose with respect to the world frame can be obtained by processing all transformations up to the world frame with a fusion algorithm (here a simple average weighted by the standard deviation of the sensor).

Possible [applications] include scenarios where some of the robots are devoid of traditional means of localization (e.g., GPS). However also if all UAVs are equipped with GPS receivers, their pose estimates can be refined with additional relative pose measurements.
